The Congress acknowledges Stewart Lee Udall's military service in World War II and his subsequent legal career after returning home. Stewart Lee Udall served in World War II and later became a lawyer. He co-founded the law firm Udall and Udall with his brother. Udall's political career began on the Amphitheater School Board, where he worked on desegregation. He then served four terms as a US Representative before being appointed Secretary of the Interior by President Kennedy in 1960. Udall's environmental achievements during his 8-year tenure made him a hero in conservation circles. During his cabinet career, Stewart Lee Udall guided landmark environmental measures through Congress, including the Wilderness Act of 1964, the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965, and the Clean Water Restoration Act of 1966. He also coauthored the Economic Opportunity Act of 1964, creating social programs like Head Start and the Job Corps. Stewart Lee Udall, as Secretary of the Interior, expanded the National Park Service by acquiring 3.85 million acres of new holdings, including 4 national parks, 6 national monuments, and various other outdoor areas. He also established the Bureau of Outdoor Recreation and announced Project EROS in 1966, advancing science and technology in the United States. During his tenure as Secretary of the Interior, Stewart Lee Udall championed the arts and initiated projects like inviting poet Robert Frost to speak at President Kennedy's inauguration. He also fought against segregation. Stewart Lee Udall continued his fight against segregation by threatening to refuse the all-White Washington Redskins access to the new stadium in Washington, DC. After leaving government service, he advocated for victims of radiation exposure, helped pass the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act in 1990, and was a prolific writer and author. Stewart Lee Udall received multiple prestigious awards for his environmental conservation efforts and advocacy for victims of nuclear weapons testing. He continued his public service through various roles until his passing in 2010. Stewart Lee Udall is to be honored with a Congressional Gold Medal for his contributions as an environmental hero, conservation champion, civil rights activist, Native American crusader, and arts advocate. The medal will be presented by the Speaker of the House and the President Pro Tempore of the Senate, with the design to be determined by the Secretary of the Treasury. Additionally, duplicate medals will be made. The Secretary has the authority to strike and sell duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal under certain regulations. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items. Proceeds from the sale will cover the cost of production. SEC. 5. AUTHORITY TO USE FUND AMOUNTS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. The United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund can be used to pay for the costs of medals struck under this Act. Proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will go back into the Fund.
